description.en: The course will introduce students to a subset of advances and current topics in the area of computer technology. The students will explore the topics and give presentations along with the opportunity to see some currently deployed systems in Estonian industry and scientific institutes.
description.et: Kursus tutvustab tudengitele mõningaid arvutitehnika valdkonna aktuaalseid teemasid ning innovatsioone. Tudengid uurivad neid teemasid ja teevad nendest ettekandeid. Lisaks on neil võimalus tutvuda mõningate olemasolevate süsteemidega nii tööstuses kui ka teadusasutustes.

objectives.en: * To give an overview of the state of the art in a subset of areas in computer technology
objectives.et: * Anda ülevaade osade arvutitehnoloogia valdkondade tehnika hetkeseisust

objectives.en: * To have the students explore and present these technologies
objectives.et: * Võimaldada tudengitele ettekannete tegemine nendel teemadel

objectives.en: * To introduce some of the local industry and the systems they have currently in use
objectives.et: * Tutvustada kohalikku tööstust ja sellest kasutatavat tehnoloogiat

learning_outcomes.en: By the end of this course the participants will have improved in:
learning_outcomes.et: Kursuse edukal läbimisel on paranenud tudengite oskus:

learning_outcomes.en: * preparing and presenting an overview of new/emerging technology;
learning_outcomes.et: * uue või varsti turule jõudva tehnoloogia ettekannete koostamises ja esitamises;

learning_outcomes.en: * understanding some of the potential advances and important questions of tomorrow in the field;
learning_outcomes.et: * mõista mõningaid hetke arengusuundi ning olulisi lahendamata probleeme;

learning_outcomes.en: * presenting "the clever idea" behind a fresh technology in a compact manner;
learning_outcomes.et: * esitada uue tehnoloogia "kavalat ideed" lühikese aja jooksul;

learning_outcomes.en: * having knowledge of the local companies and research centres either developing or deploying the discussed technologies;
learning_outcomes.et: * teadmised kohalikest ettevõtetest, kes neid tehnoloogiaid välja töötavad või rakendavad;

learning_outcomes.en: * collaboratively working on a larger document using versioning tool Git.
learning_outcomes.et: * teha koostööd kasutades dokumendi malle ja versioonihaldustööriista git suurema organiseeritud teksti loomisel.

notes.et: You will be granted access to course repositories at the beginning of the course.

independent_work.et: You will need to use git repositories to submit Your work. Templates are provided in the repositories to support you in this process.

description.et:
You will need to give total_number_of_presentation_weeks - number_of_large_presentations - number_of_compulsory_article_reviews small presentations with company added
to the Key this yields up to 40 points.
The presentations will take place in student seminars. You will need to attend at least 75% of these seminars.
You need to give larger presentations that go in depth in to the idea behind the paper. The presentations will take place in student seminars. You will need to attend at least 75% of these seminars.
You will need to attend at least 75% of these seminars where the lecturer and possibly some invited guests give presentations to give a broader look at the weekly topic.

You can gain up to 40p in the exam. You have to have the bare minimum of 30p from the semester to be eligible to take the exam. You are not obliged to take the exam if you have
* Attend seminars
* Given presentations
* Added all companies to the Key
* Attended company visits

The exam consists of
** Two microslots to present topic prepared at home, you also have to add the companies to the Key by the start of your exam
** Two microslots as lotery from the entries in the Key with up to 10 minutes to prepare for both using pen and paper

grade_preconditions.et:
* Attend seminars
* Give presentations
* Add all companies to the Key
* Attend company visits
* In case you fail to reach one or more of the above
** You will have to take the exam (Subject to minimum points requirement)

grade_evaluation.et:
In this course the grade is will be given as follows

* How to get up to 90 points:
** Taking part in Academic research seminars (Minimum attendance >= 75%) 9p
** Taking part in Corporate research seminars (Minimum attendance >= 75%) 9p
** Minimum of 3 large seminar presentations 32p. Another 11p if you do 4
** total_number_of_presentation_weeks - number_of_large_presentations - number_of_compulsory_article_reviews small presentations with company added to the Key 40p
These are upper limits of points for each activity



* How to get more points
** Early bird bonus on large presentations 5 points. These points undergo exponential decay with half life of 14 days and t0 at first presentation slot. (Can be awarded twice per student)
** Proposing and helping to organise a company visit. (Up to 10 points in total.)
** Finding and organising an external presenter to invite for one of the seminars. (Up to 10 points in total.)
** Helping to substantially improve how the Key is organised or bugfixes. (Up to 10 points in total.)
** Perfect attendance bonus - attend all seminars, 3 points (half life 1 seminar) (applies to both types separately)


* Exam
** You can gain up to 40p in the exam. You have to have the bare minimum of 30p from the semester to be eligible to take the exam
** Two microslots to present topic prepared at home, you also have to add the companies to the Key by the start of your exam
** Two microslots as lotery from the entries in the Key with up to 10 minutes to prepare for both using pen and paper
** Exam - January
** Resit - January


* Point score -> F-A grading scale
Taken that you have filled all the requirements for passing your points will be converted as follows:

** 91+ -> A
** 81+ -> B
** 71+ -> C
** 61+ -> D
** 51+ -> E
** Else -> F

description.et: Each weekly seminar will have a presentation about the weekly topic. Most will be given by the lecturer and we might have some guest speakers. These seminars will contain a considerable amount of information that will be published just months, weeks or days before the actual seminar.

Each weekly seminar in this series consists of student presentations and discussion. These seminars contain a considerable amount of information that has been published just weeks or days before the actual seminar. Most importantly decisions made by students will guide the actual papers covered.
